captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: By definition, a
car with the motor up front

that has two seats and is rear
wheel drive is a sports car.

And the car we have today
fits that criteria.

However, I'm not sure that it
actually is a sports car, and

to be honest, I'm not
sure it's actually
a muscle car either.

But I guarantee you this-- on
today's episode of "Big

Muscle," we're going
to find out.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

JIMI DAY: This is my
1969 AMX that I
fondly refer to as AM-Excess.

Well, I've wanted an AMX
for a long time.

When I was a kid, I worked in a
body shop in a small town I

was in just because I liked to
hang out there, and they had

some cool cars in there
every once in awhile.

A guy brought an AMX in
to have some paint
work done on it.

And growing up in Central
Illinois, I hadn't really seen
one before.

And as soon as I saw it, the
first thing I noticed was that
it only had two seats.
It didn't have a backseat.

So it got my curiosity up, and
I just kind of fell in love

with the car then, and I vowed
someday that I would have one.

MIKE MUSTO: So in '69, you've
got to respect the fact that

AMC actually put a lot of
go-fast tidbits on this car.

I mean, if you look at the
hood, it's nicely raised.

It's got these beautiful
scallops on it.

The bumpers are actually
recessed so there's very

little sticking out, which means
air flow is going to go
over this car very, very well.

As you move down the car, you
notice the fenders are

slightly flared,
front and back.

Now, he's got 315s on the
back of this thing
and 275s on the front.

He didn't have to tub this
car or do anything to it.
That's all AMC stuff.

So like we said, the DNA
was always in this car.

It just took somebody with the
know-how, the knowledge and

the skill and the money to
massage it, bring it out, and
build what you see here today.
[CAR ENGINE PURRING]
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
[TIRES SQUEALING]

MIKE MUSTO: Most guys don't
look at AMXes, much less

think, hey, I'm going to buy an
AMX, spend all this money,

and turn it into a bad-ass
Pro-Touring car.
But Jimi isn't most people.

Now, for you six AMX guys out
there that have always wanted

to see an AMX video,
well, guess what?
This is the video for you.

However, by the time we're done
with it, I can almost

guarantee that you're not
going to like it.

The reason you're not
going to like
this video is as follows--

aside from the sheet metal, the
grill, the glass, and the

taillights, there's really
no AMX left in this car.

You see, the motor
is a big Chevy.

The rear end is a Ford, and the
transmission is kind of a

generic unit that's come out of
a whole bunch of different

cars but that Jimi's built-up
to be pretty bulletproof.

One of the cool things about
this car is, even though Jim

has updated everything in the
car, it still has somewhat of
an old-school feel.

I mean, he did manage to keep
one old-school part--
the sun visors.
They're original.

They haven't been re-covered,
and they have a
little rust on them.
Way to keep it real, Jim.
Way to keep it real.

JIMI DAY: Yeah, die-hard AMC
fans are probably not going to

like this video, because it's a
lot easier to tell you what

modifications I didn't make on
the car versus what I did.

One of the things we're very
proud of, though, is the car

does have all its original
body panels
and glass from 1969.

It's even got the original
grill in it.

And we thought that was
important as we built the car

because I wanted to maintain
the heritage of the AMX

because it's an iconic
vehicle.

But from that point,
we scrapped just
about everything else.

We went with a modern GM
Performance Parts LS3 motor.

We went with the Keisler
5-speed transmission.

And we've got a Ford 9-inch
rear end in it, just for
reliability and durability.

Because although this car spends
probably 70% of its

time on the street, the other
30% of the time is on a track.

And I don't drive 5/10,
I drive 10/10.

So we wanted something that
was reliable, durable, and

quite honestly, something that's
efficient and easy to
buy parts for.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: Now, if you're a fan
of the show, you obviously

know that 90% of the cars we
drive are sans a little bit on
the safety equipment.

I mean, one of the last cars we
drove had a steering wheel

that would slice you like
a piece of Swiss
cheese if you got hit.

This car has more safety
equipment than most new cars.

I mean, the brakes are these
massive Willwood 6-piston pots
in the front.

They're manual, yes, but
that's just for feel.

I mean, that's the way that
Jimi likes the car.
He likes manual brakes.

As far as the suspension goes,
RideTech Triple Adjustables
all around.

Now, in a short wheelbase car,
you're going to notice a
couple of things.

One, turning on this car is
very, very aggressive.

Bring it in, turn in through the
corner, and the thing just
sticks and moves.

I mean, it's like a
flipping go-cart.

You know, most cars that you
drive, especially muscle cars,

regardless of what you do to
their suspension, I mean, they

toss around and everything
else.

But the way Jimi's got this
set up, in a heartbeat, he

could make this thing into a
wicked autocrosser a back-road

burner, or a road
course Viking.

I mean, the thing is
just ridiculous.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: The car just feels
outstanding [LAUGHS].

The turning is amazing
in this thing.
Holy crap!

I mean, he's got
these three-way
adjustable shocks on here.

And right now, they're just
on the mid setting,
and it's just great.

I mean, the car never wants to
get out of shape, out of a
focus, nothing.

And the nice part is, even if
you don't want to get too

crazy, well, it's got
so much torque.

Just keep it in a gear that's
a little bit higher, and

you've got more than enough to
pull you out of any situation.
Goddamn this thing is fun.

Holy [BLEEP], Jimi, you built
one hell of a car, buddy.
This thing is a flipping riot.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

JIMI DAY: To me, wheels are a
very important decision when

you're building a car because
wheels can make
or break any car.

I've seen a lot of really nice
cars with bad wheels on them.

And so, I went to Jason
Rushforth at Rushforth Wheels

and said, Jason, here's
my project.

And I had him do renderings,
looked at a lot
of his wheel choices.

And Jason had just come
up with a new design
called Night Train.
That's what these wheels are.

And the nice thing about
Jason's wheels
is they look great.

These were on the car at the
SEMA show, where it was chosen

as one of the top 10 cars of
SEMA But I can take this same
car to the track.

I don't have to switch
the wheels and tires.

The tire package I
have on here is--
I use the Falken Azenis 615Ks.

It's a 200 treadwear tire so
it's a great street tire.

It's legal for all of the
events we do, but
it is really sticky.

It's really sticky, it's
really durable.

The thing I like about it is
that a lot of really sticky

tires on the street will tend to
track along the street, and
these don't.

So it's a really great
all-around tire for everything
we do with the car.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: Ladies and
gentlemen, power is not the
key to making a car go fast.

It's all the other components
you have to tie in to handle
that power.

Back in the day, Pirelli had
an ad-- they said "Power is

nothing without control." And
they were 100% right.

You see, you could have
1,000 horsepower.

But if you can't stop it, if you
can't put to the ground,

if you can't control it through
the corners, then what
good is it?

Why do you think guys
that drive Miatas
love the car so much?

Handling wise, I can almost
guarantee you, this thing

would pull a G on the skid-pad,
if not more.
I mean, it feels great.
You throw it in--
Look at this!
No drama.
No anything.
Hey, how ya doin'?
Nothing!
Right?

We just go in, you throw
it in the corner.

The car doesn't do anything
it's not supposed to.

You get in this thing, you hit
the gas, the hairs on the back
of your neck stand up.

You pitch it into the corner,
dive in, hit the brakes, turn

the car in, accelerate, reach
the other way, hit the brakes,

turn into the corner,
accelerate out.

It doesn't do anything you
don't want it to do.

Holy crap, this thing
is so good!
Look at this!
Super car status!
I love it!
I want this car!
I want this car!
I want this car!
I want this car!
[SINGING]
I wanna take it home!
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

MIKE MUSTO: I'm going to tell
you right now, this car is no
longer a muscle car.
I'm not sure if it ever was.

Right now, this car is 110%
percent sports car.

In fact, I would challenge any
M3 on the planet to screw with
this car on a back road.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

JIMI DAY: I'm a muscle
car guy.

I grew up in that era, and
muscle cars are my thing.

And I've always had this dream
of being able to have a true

muscle car that will perform
like a sports car.

So that was really the impetus
behind the build of this car.

MIKE MUSTO: When we first got
a hold of Jimi Day's '69 AMX

this morning, we weren't
really sure
how to classify it.
I mean, was it a muscle car?
Was it a sports car?
We honestly didn't know.

I mean, we knew it had all the
right parts, but we didn't

know how well it worked
together.

In '69, AMC built this car, and
I don't think they knew if

they were building a
sports car or not.

What we did find
out was this--
Jimi Day took this car.

And 40 years later, he took all
the parts, and he made it

into a car that has the power of
a prize fighter, the grace

of an Olympic skier, and the
weight of a ballerina.

You put those things together
and you have a car that is

truly a jack of all trades, a
car that is just as home on

the road course as it
is on the autocross.
We drive a lot of stuff.
This car is in our top two.

That's a pretty impressive
thing for "Big Muscle."

So guys, thanks for tuning in,
thanks for hanging with us

with this crazy frickin' AMX
that we fell in love with.

Stay tuned next week
for another
episode of "Big Muscle."

title: Feels like a Porsche? Yes. 1969 AMX - /Big Muscle

comments.text:
The Ford 9 inch is a great choice,I still think the AMC engine is a better 
choice,aluminum heads are available,the AMC motors are a compact big

street,make a reliable 600 hp﻿
comments.author: inagod

comments.text: how often was this video renamed by now ? ;)﻿
comments.author: The Sheepherd

comments.text:
For a road course car, removing weight from the front is very important. 
AMC V8 components can be had in aluminum, but my guess would be that the 
bare block and heads probably cost close to as much as this complete 
engine, and would still probably weigh more. My plans for my 1967 Camaro 
include an LS engine, and a Ford rear end. You could argue that it's still 
a Chevrolet engine, but it really is just as non stock in a first 
generation Camaro as it is in an AMC AMX.﻿

comments.author: Jacob Fisher

comments.text:
The LS engines are kind of the "go to" for a reliable power plant these 
days.  I can see why that's what he used. Seems if you want a reliable V8 
that you can get parts for nearly anywhere in the Americas, if not the 
world, you go with the LS. An AMC 401 or 390 would be nice but finding the 
right go fast parts is probably a lot of work and wouldn't have the 
aftermarket support for what it looks like he does/wants.  I would LOVE to 
have that AMX in my driveway. If you ever think of selling.....﻿

comments.author: w41duvernay

comments.text:
+Josh Black No.  He couldn't have.  This car is a high end pro-touring 
build.  It was built to handle, right?  Now...tell me.  What does a 401 
weigh?  Here's a hint:  Almost 200 lbs more than an LS3.  Are you starting 
to get the picture?  A 401, in addition to having almost no aftermarket 
support would destroy the handling of this car.
comments.author: entropy156

comments.text:

chevy-stangs!
comments.author: Alexander Rahl

comments.text:

are reasons why LS swaps are so popular, they're more reliable and more 
available than many other high performance engines.
comments.author: Jacinth Gudetti

comments.text:
+Adam Kellar Sorry, Adam it didn't. When I saw the pic of the LS1, I just 
ASSumed that he didn't. It's going to get real OLD on taking a 
NON-manufacturer engine and putting in a classic car. Especially with 
todays technology available for the AMC engine. I don't feel OLD, despite 
going to high school in the 80s.
comments.author: w41duvernay

comments.text:
+w41duvernay did you read? He had a 401 and went all original restoration 
in the beginning. He just decided to go a different route later to suit his 
interests. It gets old hearing people preach sensationalism and hate when 
someone does something different than what they would do.
comments.author: Adam Kellar

comments.text:
+Adam Kellar This car is really nice. I would have liked it if they had 
went with an AMC 390/401 v8. The problem is each one of these older engine 
have their own characteristic, which has been changed due to the fuel 
injection. Nothing drives me more crazy than watching a NON manufacturer 
engine being dropped in a classic musclecar.

with a hoped up 390 or 401.

I'd love to have this car.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Alex Robic

comments.text:
I get it that it is cheaper to put a Chevy motor in it, but AMC engine 
blocks are excellent for building high horsepower engines.  They have a 
higher nickel content than any other engine made which makes them 
bulletproof.  650hp is not hard to make with an AMC.  Back in the day, 
Penske and Mark Donohue won the Trans-Am championship with the Javelin 
because they had the best motor.﻿
comments.author: Joshua M

comments.text:
I agree 100%. My 1 401 puts out 450 hp@4800 RPMs. It has factory forged 
bottom end, but yes every other part is 2x the $ of a Chev. Bummer being 
different sometimes! At 100+k it still had the cross-hatch on the 
cylinder-bores. This is an engine 4 off road, low end TQ. And AMC has a 
loyal following, so many parts are out there & others being made from 
original tooling. I've never seen a rod go thru a high nickel AMC  block. 
Not to knock Chevs, it's just they don't belong EVERYWHERE!

comments.author: silvernail6

comments.text:
I have read most of the reply's and I can see both sides. I don't have a 
AMX but I have close friends that do having said that now let me say the 
390 motor is a strong torque monster. Now if you look up Rambler AMX race 
you will see true AMC guys with stay true to your brand mentality. I find 
no problem with doing what you want to what you own and this guy has done a 
fantastic job of making his car his own. I was reading the reply's and a 
lot of them say the sound of the motor I have to say the AMC motors sound 
just as good. And with the right build will spin 7000 to nearly 8000 and 
sound so good doing it not to take away from how this sounds. I like the 
sound of this LS as well. So what I was getting to is to all the guys out 
there building a car do it your way its your car. Don't let somebody talk 
you into keeping a motor you don't want or buying a motor you don't think 
you need... It's your car build it to your specifications let the haters 
take the heel-toe express just get out there and build a car that's all 
that matters get your car on this show and be proud....       ﻿

comments.author: The Sheepherd

comments.text:
LS motors are great power plants,but in the case of AMC engines,the stock 
360-401 motors are great pieces.Reliable engine's in the 500 - 600 BHP can 
be put together using standard engine parts,Stock steel crank,rods,ARP head 
studs,rod bolts,Edelbrock Torker or Offenhauser intakes,ported dog leg 
heads,flat top pistons.For even more power Indy components have some trick 
heads,intakes available that should get you around 800 bhp without a 
turbo,blower or nitrous.Plus you get a big choice in 4,5 
speeds,automatics,727,904,turbo 400 etc,rear ends,bolt in a 9 inch Ford 
early or later﻿

comments.author: Lucas A.M.

comments.text:
Okay, its got a LS3 Chevy and ford diff in it, but it was built for a road 
course...its still an AMX. 
If the #'s didn't match when he bought bit, it doesn't matter. It'll kick 
the crap out ta any AMX with the stock 390...hands down. Yeah, I'm a 
purist, but I bet that car was a blast to drive. ﻿
comments.author: Dave Helmboldt

comments.text: Fuck you.I'm done. No AMC engine= No Fucks Given. Eat shit and die slow.﻿
comments.author: Ronald Colman

comments.text:
+Ronald Colman You people are being fucking stupid.  It's a Pro Touring 
car.  Built to look old and perform new. An AMX shell filled with very 
modern parts. Just like *all* Pro Touring cars.  Tell me....what does a 390 
weigh.  Now....what does an LS3 weigh? Think that weight difference might 
affect how the car handles? The front and rear suspension are completely 
aftermarket, the trans is a modern swap, the rear end is the ubiquitous 9" 
Ford....but probably an aftermarket version, the interior is filled with a 
cage, racing seats and electronics....and you guys are going to bitch about 
the *engine swap?*  Really?  I mean....fuckin' *REALLY?!*  Save your 
bullshit purist outrage. It's not like he cut up a concourse Go Pak car.  
 People who see that car see an AMX kicking the absolute shit out of six 
figure Eurotrash on a track....because they can appreciate the sausage 
without thinking too much about how it was made.
comments.author: entropy156

comments.text:
+Ronald Colman i understand your point completely. and 9/10 i like these 
cars with their original engines. but look at it this way, we dont know 
what condition the engine was in when he bought it. the ls might have been 
cheaper. and for a pro touring car, i get the ls choice. they're common, 
very well understood by every engine builder in the country and the parts 
are very plentiful. when it comes to racecars, parts break. and i can fully 
understand wanting an engine that has easy to replace parts in addition to 
performance. hell, im doing the same thing with a datsun 280z i bought 
recently for that reason. but those old amc engines are still amazing
comments.author: Will Young

comments.text:
Agreed, they used brakes powersteering and other ancilliary components form 
all the big three, but always had their own engines. That's why I feel so 
strongly. They had great engines with forged cranks that could run head to 
head with anything from Ford, Chrysler, or Chevy. Amc was killed and eaten 
by the "Big Three".
comments.author: Ronald Colman

comments.text:
+Ronald Colman
Dude just chill to every man his own. Everyone has their preference. Some 
of the original AMC cars just were thrown together with parts from all 3 of 
the big campanies, from the factory. Ford, Chevy, and Dodge. No need to 
flip the fuck out.
comments.author: sean

comments.text:
Seriously? The whole purpose of having an MC is to have a different kind of 
car than everything else. If I wanted an LS I'd find a GM car. I stand by 
my opinion that I do not like this car because, LS engine in it. So, go eat 
paste in the corner.
comments.author: Ronald Colman

comments.text: Retard

comments.text:
I was all in and happy to see it until they flashed that LS engine, at 
which point I stopped the video...for the amount of money spent there 
could've still been an AMC V8 in it. Damn, nowadays the OG engine could've 
even been updated to fuel injection! I know, cuz I had been researching 
injection for my 68 390 go pak car right before I sold her. I have to agree 
with you here.

comments.text:
Just another chevy motor in classic , tsk , tsk . Stop filming those guys ,

comments.author: Neil Macleod

comments.text:
Need more AMX, because they are still true American Classics. This is

comments.author: Joe11Blue

comments.text:
The valve train is junk,good rockers are needed,CM pushrods etc.71 and 
later 401 had the 727,less ring gear,had a flexplate,GM 400 used a adapter 
in Jeep,Early 390's need a adapter and machining to the crank for the [AMC 
bolt pattern only]727 to work,plus a shorter driveshaft[you have 
shortened].I had a 727 in my 69 AMX.T-10 in 390.
comments.author: inagod

comments.text:
nice choice for awap ,but the AMC motors are big and bad,quick stroke ,big 
cubes,steel crank and rods,put a set of Indy or other aluminum heads.500 
-600 hp .It is a 2 seat sports car,duh.It is a very modern looking 
design.the Ford rear is needed,thought the stock Amc can be upgraded with 
mods to the hubs,better gears,its just not worth it.The trunnion front 
suspension is light weight and can be upgraded,.
comments.author: inagod

comments.text:

comments.text:
yes AMC used parts from the big 3 and made it work good IE the lifters are

part]), chrysler 727& 904. Jeep FSJ was GM TH400 from 71-79.
